Review: Spectre

Following the immensely successful previous film in the James Bond series, Spectre fails to live up to expectations, says Rhys Thompson

Review: Suffragette

The much anticipated film about the Suffragette movement well documents the struggles women faced in acquiring the vote in Britain, whilst also serving as a reminder for how the fight must continue on a global scale in 2015, says Kate Barlow

Review: Crimson Peak

Blood-soaked and beautiful, Crimson Peak is part Hitchcockian thriller, part gothic romance, and entirely brilliant, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Macbeth

By James Bithell

Kurzel's film adaption of Macbeth truly lives up to the beauty and power of the original play, says Simran Virdee

Review: Regression

Good performances from Ethan Hawke and Emma Watson aren't enough to save this horribly misjudged film, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: The Intern

By James Bithell

The Intern proves to be an inoffensively pointless film that even its cast can't save, says Louis Chilton

Review: Solace

The terrible quality of this film about a psychic doctor hunting down a serial killer is something that you'd wish you could have foretold before watching it, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Everest

The most hostile environment on Earth makes the perfect setting for a thoroughly engaging disaster movie, says Tom Parkes

Review: 45 Years

By James Bithell

Andrew Haigh's film of an ordinary couple celebrating an anniversary is 'pure poetry in the domestic space', says Laura Hancock

Review: The Visit

Unpretentious and darkly funny, The Visit marks a return to form for M Night Shyamalan, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Legend

Tom Hardy is becoming such a legendary actor that for this gangster film they chose to cast him twice, says Simran Virdee

Review: Man From U.N.C.L.E.

Despite a weak plot, Guy Ritchie's cinematic reboot of the '60s TV classic is an enjoyable espionage caper, says Laura Hancock

Review: Sinister 2

This sequel lacks the atmosphere of its predecessor, but makes up for it with great performances and sympathetic characters, says Lauren McNeilage

Review: Dragon Ball Z: Resurrection 'F'

When you revive a classic villain from a show's past, you also breathe new life into the interest of fans who have forgotten the series, says Liam Dooley.

Review: Fantastic Four

Fox's 2015 reboot of the Fantastic Four delves into some interesting territory but ultimately comes up feeling underdeveloped and rushed, says Liam Dooley.

Review: Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation

Tom Cruise's latest outing as Ethan Hunt provides amazing action sequences without wasting too much time trying to amend the franchise's record, says Simran Virdee.

Review: Song of the Sea

By James Bithell

Rooted in folklore, Song of the Sea provides a stunningly intimate magical drama, says Laura Hancock

Review: Inside Out

Pixar's latest film offers a fantastic exploration into human emotions, says Thomas Ron

Review: Ant-Man

Marvel Studios' latest addition appears pretty minuscule standing against the quality of their previous work, says Liam Dooley.

Review: Terminator: Genisys

Arnold Schwarzenegger is back in a franchise that should never be terminated, says Liam Dooley.

Review: Mr. Holmes

Sir Ian McKellen gives a masterful performance in a captivating new take on the world's most famous detective, says Rhys Thompson

Review: Jurassic World

By James Bithell

Colin Trevorrow's return to the Jurassic is more postmodern than prehistoric. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Spy

The spy film genre is sharply mocked in Paul Feig's latest film. Rhys Thompson reviews.

Review: Danny Collins

By James Bithell

Al Pacino stars in a washed-up rock star tale that's fun but predictable, says Liam Dooley

Review: The Connection

By James Bithell

The period atmosphere is heavy as Jean Dujardin chases gangsters in 1970s Marseilles. Ben Phillips reviews

Review: Tomorrowland: A World Beyond

By James Bithell

A teenage girl discovers a new world in an original but frustrating take on the sci-fi genre, says Helena Sutcliffe

Review: Mad Max: Fury Road

By James Bithell

Mad Max: Fury Road is a staggering post-apocalyptic thrill-ride for everyone except Men's Rights Activists, says Alex Killeen

Review: Pitch Perfect 2

By James Bithell

Pitch Perfect 2 sticks closely to the formula of the original film, for better or worse, says Maria Correa

Review: Far from the Madding Crowd

By James Bithell

Despite some moments of over-romanticism, this new Thomas Hardy adaptation is a welcome addition to the period drama field, says Matthew Edwards

Review: Spooks: the Greater Good

Kicking off a few years after the TV series finished, Spooks: the Greater Good provides a thrilling cinematic experience for new and old fans alike. Rhys Thompson reviews.
